It may be used freely by individuals for research, teaching, and personal use as long as this statement of availability is included in the text. For all other use contact the Special Collections Librarian, Hoskins Library, University of Tennessee, 1401 Cumberland Avenue, Knoxville, TN 37996. (865) 974-4480.

bibl.title: [Legal document] 1789, Washington County, Tennessee
bibl.note: This is a complaint letter dated 1789 filed by David Taylor concerning an unpaid debt owned by Valentine Sevier, son of Governor John Sevier.

projectDesc.p: Created for the University of Tennessee Digital Library

editorialDecl.p: Quotation marks retained as data except inside q tags
Errors in transcription of the printed text controlled with X-Metal 2.1 spell-checker; text has also been thoroughly proofread.
Corrections and normalization represented by editorial tags.
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

refsDecl.p: ID attributes provided for only those pages, chapters, or illustrations toward which a reference or figure points.

div1.p: John Tadlockassine of David Taylor complains of Valentine Sevier in custody of the Sheriff overstrike for that wheras the afsd. Valentine Sevier on the eleventh day August one thousand seven hundred and eighty nine in the County aforsaid did give an Order on James Stuart Esquire for the sum of twenty two pounds Virginia Currancy equal to twenty nine pounds six shillings and Eight pence North CarolinaCurrancy with lawfull Interest for the same from the year 1779 untill paid, which said order the said David Taylor afterwardsvz. on the day of in the county afsd. did assign over to John Tadlock all his right and interest therin, which order the said Valentine Sevier faithfully promised that he would well and truly pay and satisfy unto the said David Taylor if the same should be protested by the said James Stuart, afterwardsVz. on the fourth day of Sepr. one thousand seven hundred Eight nine in the County afsd. he the said James Stuart the order afsd. did protest and altogether refuse to pay nevertheless the said Valentine Sevier not ignorant of his promise and afsd. hath neglected to pay any part or penny therof although often theruntoassumpsit required. Wherfore the sd. John Tadlock saith he is injured to the value of one hundred pounds & therfore sees &c
